content.description: A variation of Ebriosity that starts on the same sloper rail and heads left with a powerful, tricky topout.
Climbs the amazing tall vertical face of the 5 star boulder
content.location: Start on crimps at chest height in a right angling crack. Difficult climbing leads to an easier topout nice and high up there.

content.description: On the back (north) side of the boulder, on the far right side, there is a series of sloping rails. This problem is a sit start on slopers that moves up and right to top out on jugs on the face above. Easily identifiable by the opposing sidepulls about 12 inches apart on the roof. Fun problem involving a bunch of heel trickery (for me, anyway). Apparently the lowest start gets a 7 and the higher rail start gets a 6, but there doesn't seem to be any difference in difficulty
content.protection: Couple pads and a spotter to keep your head from smacking the rock when your heel gets stuck in the heel hook...

content.description: Tensiony, techy moves made easier with good beta lead into the fun, powerful finish of Ross Bongo.
content.location: Start on the leftmost obvious edges on the gently overhanging face left of Ross Bongo, climbing right using some trickery into the original Ross Bongo line.

content.description: The really fun arete/face on the southeast corner of the boulder.  Sit start, moves up on edges and pinches using a fun knee bar.  Hard moves bumping left onto the face and tossing left and up to a good edge (using heel and toe trickery along the way).
content.location: the first problem you come to from the approach.

content.description: This route is on the shorter West side of the boulder. Start matched on the lowest part of the Sobriosity rail, and climb right and up, topping out on better holds.
content.location: Find the start to Sobriosity, and sit with your hands matched on the lowest part of the rail. Move right and up. A harder variation starts on the even lower rail.

content.description: Starts on Five Star Arret, works left in dihedral with sloppy jug, pinch and gaston.
Start five feet right of The Five Star Arete, look for a left facing crimp rail at about shoulder height move left to a gaston then finish with big moves on good holds.

The huge intimidating arete to the left of Ross Bongo. Start sitting on a small boulder at the base of the arete on a slopey shelf. Work up the arete to the high sloper, make a big reach right to a positive edge, and top out straight above on good holds. Don't let the landing spook you, the ground is flat exactly where it needs to be.

Fun route to the left of ebriosity, start down low in the pit on an obvious incut crimp/jug.  Move up through gradually worsening slopers to the lip (crux) and then solo the heady but easy face to the top.
content.protection: As many pads as you can comfortably carry.

content.description:
Start on the incut ledge at the left end of the steep face (to the left of Green Padded Ass). Work through some nice jugs to a couple trickier moves on some crimpers before it slabs out.

As of at least 8/13/20 the really big jug about halfway up and like 3 moves before the slab feels a bit loose. Be very careful on this hold for your own safety and also for the lasting integrity of the problem as it is.
content.protection: Pad(s). This thing is really very tall.

climbs.name: The Five Star Lip
climbs.fa: Unsure. If anyone knows tell me and I'll add it.

content.description: Stand start on the worlds coolest pinch and a small crack for a foot directly to the right of the arête. Climb up and left through good but slightly hidden holds and big moves to a very hidden jug up top.
content.protection: Pad or two is prob a good idea. Landing is flat-ish but there are some small rocks in the way.
content.location: This starts on the SouthWest arête of The Five Star Boulder. If you hike in from the 2.8 mile pullout and take a left off the main trail (once you're in the forest) at the fork to get to the Five Star Boulder it will be the first thing you run into on the boulder directly ahead of you. It is directly to the left of Takes a Village (V13) and to the right (and 1 floor down) from Fingey Crack (V0).

content.description: This excellent Washington classic starts at the bottom of the wall to the left of the arête on opposing jugs. From here make your way up and right to 2 less than ideal crimps on the arête itself. Some heel trickery or raw strength will take you to the jug past the crimps and to the highball slab top out above.
content.protection: There is a large boulder directly underneath the start. You'll want to bring at least one pad to cover this boulder + however many more you'd like to pad the surrounding area. Also this thing is really tall.

climbs.name: Fingey Crack
climbs.fa: Unsure. If anyone knows tell me and I'll add it.

content.description: Climb the obvious vertical crack straight up the featured face. Everything is on everything is fun.
content.protection: Pad/Spotter maybe? Landing is flat but you are on a sort of suspended platform halfway up the boulder so really you might just want a spotter to make sure you don't fall backwards and roll off the whole ass boulder.
content.location: This problem is on the First Floor of the Five Star Boulder. If you're looking at The Five Star Lip (V2) there is a very easy scramble up the boulder directly to the left. Do not go all the way to the top but instead, stop on a clearing about halfway up the boulder which I call the First Floor. Fingey Crack is the crack line directly up the boulder from here to the Second Floor.

content.description: The line of slopers starting by the right side cave route and going left and up.  I haven't done this problem, so my only knowledge about the name and quality comes from Dave, but I figured it's good to get problems posted on here.  Comments welcome - who has done this rig?
